info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 75.  Nancy Zerg ends Ken's streak.

(Jerry Seinfield: The Seinfeld gang is out of jail--)
(George Costanza: --and coming to Jeopardy!--)
(Cosmo Kramer: --for a category.)
(Elaine Benes: Stay tuned!)

(2, 1).clue: Days celebrating people going to heaven include Jesus' Ascension day & her Assumption day

(3, 1).clue: In 1998 Rabbit Hash, Kentucky elected Goofy, one of these, as mayor; sadly, the mayor had to be "put down" in 2001

(6, 1).clue: (Jerry Seinfeld reads the clue.)  This Season 7 episode revealed that this store owner was based on a real person"Very good.  You know something?""Hm?""No soup for you!"

(2, 2).clue: Bitter herbs are featured on this holiday's Seder plate

(3, 2).clue: Peter Ueberroth finished sixth in a 2003 race for this state's highest office, just ahead of Larry Flynt

(4, 2).clue: In a 1775 speech he declared, "I know not what course others may take..." yada yada yada

(6, 2).clue: "A Christmas present?""That's right.""For who?""For you!""Oh!  Get out of here!"(Julia Louis-Dreyfus [Elaine Benes] reads the clue.)  In that scene from Season 3, George's gift to Elaine was this article of clothing--a bargain because of a flaw: a small red dot

(2, 3).clue: In 1939 FDR moved this holiday one week earlier in an attempt to please the retail industry

(3, 3).clue: This George W. Bush Cabinet member lost his 2000 Senate race to a man who died a month before the election

(4, 3).clue: In a 1974 national TV address he conveyed, "Our long national nightmare is over..." yada yada yada

(5, 3).clue: The "hour" for a military action to start

(6, 3).clue: "She tells me that her ex-boyfriend was over late last night and 'yada yada yada', I'm really tired today.'""What do you think she was tired from?""Well obviously the 'yada yada.'"(Jason Alexander [George Costanza] reads the clue.)  That was a classic scene from Season 8; "yada yada yada" recently made it into one edition of this venerable British dictionary

(2, 4).clue: In 1876 Montreal's Mount Royal Park was officially inaugurated on May 24, a Canadian holiday because it's her birthday

(3, 4).clue: 1984 Walter Mondale got his 13 electoral votes by winning D.C. & this state

(4, 4).clue: Before Congress in 1951, he announced, "I now close my military career..." yada yada yada

(5, 4).clue: William Cowper: "What peaceful hours I once enjoyed... but they have left an aching" this

(6, 4).clue: "I'm out."(Michael Richards [Cosmo Kramer] reads the clue.)  When he wrote that classic episode from Season 4, this Seinfeld co-creator turned curbing his enthusiasm into an Emmy

(2, 5).clue: In 1955 the Pope moved the service from this observance, including St. John's Passion, to the afternoon

(3, 5).clue: In 1884 a booster's attack on democratic "Rum, Romanism & Rebellion" backfired on this Down Easter

(4, 5).clue: He humbly shared with the British in 1936: "A few hours ago I discharged my last duty as king..." yada yada yada

(5, 5).clue: 9-letter word for lack of existence, or a person of no importance

(6, 5).clue: (Jerry Seinfeld reads the clue.)  Kramer dated a "low-talker" who designed this, also the title of the episode from Season 5"I... I can't wear this!""Hey, this looks better than anything you own."

(1, 1).clue: Giraffes are divided by sex into cows & these

(3, 1).clue: This "Grand Ole Opry" comedy star used to wear a straw hat with the $1.98 price tag still attached

(4, 1).clue: In 1909 George S. Patton graduated 46th out of 103 at this institution

(5, 1).clue: Tom Kelly took the 1949 nude photographs of this actress that later appeared on the calendar "Golden Dreams"

(6, 1).clue: Wifebeater is a controversial slang term for this ribbed white item of apparel

(1, 2).clue: While swimming, the anaconda can close off a valve inside these to keep water out

(3, 2).clue: Featured in the "Harry Potter" movies, this hat takes its name from its function at Hogwarts School

(4, 2).clue: Patton placed 5th at the 1912 Olympics in this event that includes swimming, fencing & the pistol

(5, 2).clue: A wavy fabric made by twisting & then relaxing yarn, it's also found before "de Chine"

(6, 2).clue: This kind of fruit is a Bronx cheer

(1, 3).clue: It's the common litter size of llamas, hippos & kangaroos

(3, 3).clue: Goya liked to paint at night, so he wore a hat rimmed with these

(4, 3).clue: In 1916 Patton was an acting aide to this man, commander of WWI's American Expenditionary Forces

(5, 3).clue: In 1956 the first transatlantic telephone cable was laid between Oban, Scotland & Clarenville in this Canadian province

(6, 3).clue: This slang term for a fool or dolt is also the name of one of Archie's Riverdale friends

(1, 4).clue: One type of terrier was specially bred in England to hunt this other member of the dog family

(2, 4).clue: The New York Islanders' home ice

(3, 4).clue: The name of this often brimless hat, popular in the 1920s, is French for "bell", after the shape of the hat

(4, 4).clue: On December 26, 1944 Patton's forces relieved this town in Belgium's Ardennes; the Germans were driven out in January

(5, 4).clue: The most popular color for this November birthstone is a rich orange-yellow, like the color of sherry

(6, 4).clue: A university seminar on slang revealed that an unwelcome follower is known as a hanging this

(1, 5).clue: As it's a fave of caribou, the lichen they eat is called this moss

(3, 5).clue: In Wagner's operas, this eldest Valkyrie is stereotypically dressed in a horned helmet & breastplate

(4, 5).clue: A few feet of the 998 square miles of this European country are Patton's grave in the American cemetery

(5, 5).clue: This Ballets Russes founder had tried to be a composer, but Rimsky-Korsakov told him to stop

(6, 5).clue: From the Latin for "duchy", it's slang for money or for a show ticket

(0, 0).clue: Most of this firm's 70,000 seasonal white-collar employees work only 4 months a year
